Virtual Boxing

Inspiration

Party games, as well as any friendly competitive games, are wildly popular among people of all ages. By making a boxing game, people are enticed to compete with each other and ultimately have fun.

What it does

Using the Oculus Rift we are able to virtually interact with a fully functioning punching bag, which interacts appropriately according to physics, to give an experience that is reminiscent of professional boxing. In addition to tracking hands using the Leap Motion, we track feet movements using the Myo.

How I built it

C# and Unity were used.

Challenges I ran into

The Myo was a new piece of hardware that was used, which led to many short term problems concerning appropriate usage.

Accomplishments that I'm proud of

Virtual Boxing has positional tracking that is normally only associated with the HTC Vive. This effect was able to be emulated using an Oculus Rift.

What's next for Virtual Boxing

The addition of multiplayer (over LAN or the internet) is the next major goal.

Built With

  • c#
  • unity
  • oculus
  • leap-motion
  • myo
  • 3ds-max

mapTax

• Separating the drives between two or more jobs

  • Monthly mileage and approximate deductible tax according to IRS

  • start up screen of iOS app(IOT device).

  • Start button resturns the GPS coordinates for every 10 mins

  • App runs on background and post the GPS coordinated into AWS RDS(mySQL).

Inspiration

Taking the advantage of iOT(internet of things) devices to calculate the accurate time spent on different businesses and add significant value to professional life.

What it does

It is a web and iOS app that can track the location and can calculates the milage a user did for multiple jobs there by providing user a clear estimate of deductible tax for separately.

How I built it

We built an iOS app to track the location of the user which posts the latitudes and longitudes of the user's location into aws RDS(mySQL). We created an Amazon EC2 instance for Ubuntu and created a web server in it. Our web client uses this data and gives report to the user which has the estimates of the miles ran and calculates the tax deductibles separately for multiple jobs.

Challenges I ran into

Setting up Amazon web service was a real challenge.

Accomplishments that I'm proud of

Working on Amazon Web services was in my wish list since a long time. I accomplished it and it is super cool.

What I learned

Basics of Ubuntu and AWS.

What's next for mapTax

Our future enhancements includes smart watch app for apple watch, android wear and pebble.

Built With

  • amazon-web-services
  • amazon-ec2
  • ios
  • swift
  • php
  • mysql
UListen

Inspiration

When I was younger, I had a friend whose mother was deaf. I always admired how my friend could communicate without speaking and I thought it would be cool if I could help people learn and communicate in the same way my childhood friend did.

What it does

We have built an IPhone app that allows people to view sign language terms so they may repeat them to a hearing impaired person.

How I built it

We used Apple's programming language Swift to build the app.

Challenges I ran into

We ran into the problem of how to store multiple videos under the same tag and have them all play through slow enough so the user is able to see them.

Accomplishments that I'm proud of

We are proud of getting the app to show a particular gif when we press a certain word.

What I learned

We learned how to better use Swift and how Dictionaries work.

What's next for UListen

We plan on allowing users to search for certain terms instead of scrolling through a list. We also hope to allow users to input their own gifs, and have a user input text that would turn into a string sign language gifs.

Built With

  • ios
  • iphone-sdk
  • asl

We made it move.

• Front

  • Right Side

  • Back Side

  • Left Side

  • Rear

  • Before

We made it move.

This is our team's very first Hackathon and submission.

Among the free stickers, t-shirts and other awesome stuff given away at the HackYSU event, toy green DUMP TRUCKS were given away.

We made it our job to make it being able to be controlled! The original idea was to use a Photon or an Intel Edison to make the truck controlled via wireless, however, the change to USB was made due to limitations. The goal was to host a web server other hackers could join and input the commands "UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT or STOP." All inputs would be recorded for a few seconds and after that, whatever input had the most votes, the truck would move. We were going to design a course hackers would have to work together to complete, but without wireless it would not b possible.

piTunes

Inspiration

Developers create unique code all the time! What if that code was able to generate unique music? That's the idea that inspired us.

What it does

As you type or code, piTunes plays music based on the letters, numbers, and characters you type!

How we built it

We used the raspberry pi and interfaced it with the sonic pi.

Challenges we ran into

We had a hard time getting it up to domains.com since the link is broken

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We are really proud of our punny identity! Along with that, we are inspired by the potential to produce unique music while typing unique code.

What we learned

We learned that consistent failure leads to success

What's next for piTunes

We want to take it to the next level and add more sound kits or sets of sounds per letter to see the kinds of melodies that can be produced while writing unique code.

  • sonic-pi

Will It Win?

• Paste a project description into the form.

  • Our model will attempt to predict whether a project will win an award.

  • The hackathon Auto-Judge is still learning to distinguish winning projects from the rest.

Inspiration

We both wanted to sharpen our data science skills and make a super meta hackathon project at the same time.

What it does

Given only text from a devpost project description, our app predicts whether or not that project will win an award.

How we built it

First, we scraped every single project on devpost. (Python, beautiful-soup) We then trained classifiers on "bag-of-words" representations of the projects. (scikit-learn: PCA, SVM) Finally, we deployed our model to the web to fulfill it's destiny as an automated hackathon judge.

Challenges we ran into

  1. Scraping devpost was a pain in the rear. Why do they not have an official API???
  2. Text data can be counterintuitive. We did a bunch of stuff we though should substantially improve model performance. Our test accuracy decreased. FML frownie-face.
  3. It turns out, our model only predicts losses. If 30 percent of all projects get some kind of prize, we can achieve 70 percent accuracy by classifying all projects as non-winners. We have failed to show that word counts can distinguish winning hackathon projects from the rest.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

  • We scraped almost 50 MB of project descriptions from devpost
  • We learned some tough lessons about what can go wrong when building a classifier.
  • We made it to the final round in the cup stacking competition.

What we learned

  • How to build a classifier and put it on the web.
  • "Better than a coin-toss" doesn't mean your model isn't worthless.

What's next for Will It Win?

Deep Learning and hackathon project creation using "Deep Dream." trippy...

Built With

  • python
  • sklearn
  • scikit-learn
  • beautiful-soup
  • flask
  • highcharts
